title: Pest Control
description: Comprehensive pest control requirements including pest-free products and packaging, facility pest management, monitoring devices, exclusion measures, and professional pest control program documentation

requirements.text: Are products or ingredients free of pests (e.g., insects, rodents, birds, reptiles, mammals) or any evidence of them? ANY DOWN SCORE IN THIS QUESTION RESULTS IN AN AUTOMATIC FAILURE OF THE AUDIT.
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Presence of pests or pest evidence in products or ingredients represents an immediate and critical food safety hazard that can result in contamination with pathogens, allergens, filth, or toxins. This poses unacceptable public health risks and violates fundamental food safety requirements.
mandatoryStatements: All products and ingredients must be completely free of pests including insects, rodents, birds, reptiles, and mammals
Products must be free of any evidence of pest activity including droppings, gnaw marks, or nesting materials
Any pest presence in products results in automatic audit failure
Immediate quarantine and investigation required for any pest detection in products
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily visual inspection of all products and ingredients for pest presence or evidence, immediate response to any findings
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Continuous monitoring during production, receiving inspection for pest evidence, immediate halt of operations if pests detected in products

requirements.text: Are packaging supplies free of pests (e.g., insects, rodents, birds, reptiles, mammals) or any evidence of them? ANY DOWN SCORE IN THIS QUESTION RESULTS IN AN AUTOMATIC FAILURE OF THE AUDIT.
requirements.automaticFailureReason: Pest contamination of packaging materials can directly transfer to food products during packaging operations. This represents a critical breakdown in food safety controls and creates unacceptable contamination risks throughout the production chain.
mandatoryStatements: All packaging supplies must be completely free of pests and pest evidence
Packaging storage areas must prevent pest access and contamination
Any pest contamination of packaging results in automatic audit failure
Packaging must be inspected before use for pest evidence
requirements.verificationExpectations: Daily inspection of packaging storage areas and supplies for pest activity, immediate quarantine of contaminated materials
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Visual inspection of packaging materials before use, continuous monitoring of packaging storage conditions

requirements.text: Are plant and storage areas free of pests (e.g., insects, rodents, birds, reptiles, mammals) or any evidence of them?
mandatoryStatements: Plant and storage areas must be maintained free of pests and pest evidence
Regular inspections must be conducted to detect pest presence
Evidence of pest activity must be addressed immediately with corrective actions
Sanitation practices must support pest-free environment
requirements.verificationExpectations: Weekly comprehensive facility inspection for pest presence or evidence, monthly third-party pest control service verification
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Daily visual monitoring during operations, immediate response to any pest sightings or evidence

requirements.text: Is the area outside the facility free of evidence of pest activity?
mandatoryStatements: Exterior areas must be maintained to minimize pest harborage and activity
Evidence of pest activity outside must be monitored and controlled
Exterior pest control measures must prevent pest entry to facility
Vegetation, debris, and conditions supporting pest activity must be managed
requirements.verificationExpectations: Monthly exterior grounds inspection for pest harborage conditions and activity evidence
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly visual monitoring of exterior perimeter, immediate action for pest activity near facility

requirements.text: Is there an effective pest control program in place? A ZERO (NON-CONFORMANCE) SCORE IN THIS QUESTION RESULTS IN AN AUTOMATIC FAILURE OF THE AUDIT.
requirements.automaticFailureReason: The complete absence of an effective pest control program represents a fundamental failure to implement preventive food safety controls. Without a documented pest control system, the facility cannot demonstrate adequate protection of food products from pest contamination and associated microbiological hazards.
mandatoryStatements: A documented and effective pest control program must be implemented and maintained
Program must include monitoring, prevention, and corrective action procedures
Pest control service provider must be licensed and qualified
Pest control records must be maintained and reviewed regularly
Absence of pest control program results in automatic audit failure
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual review of pest control program effectiveness, quarterly verification of pest control service records and trend analysis
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly or monthly pest control device monitoring per program requirements, documented verification of all service visits

requirements.text: Are pest control devices located away from exposed raw materials, work-in-progress, ingredients (including water and ice), finished goods and packaging, and poisonous bait stations are not used within the facility?
mandatoryStatements: Pest control devices must be located away from exposed food products and materials
Minimum safe distance (6 feet) must be maintained from exposed products
Poisonous bait stations must not be used inside the facility
Only mechanical traps or non-toxic monitoring devices permitted in production areas
requirements.verificationExpectations: Semi-annual audit of pest control device locations against facility map, verification no poisonous baits inside facility
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly verification during pest control monitoring that devices maintain proper distance from products

requirements.text: Are pest control devices maintained in a clean and intact condition and marked as monitored (or bar code scanned) on a regular basis?
mandatoryStatements: All pest control devices must be maintained in clean and intact condition
Devices must be marked or electronically scanned to document monitoring
Regular monitoring schedule must be established and followed
Damaged devices must be repaired or replaced immediately
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly audit of device condition and monitoring documentation completeness
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly or monthly device inspection and monitoring per program schedule, immediate repair of damaged devices

requirements.text: Are interior and exterior building perimeter pest control devices adequate in number and location?
mandatoryStatements: Pest control device coverage must be adequate for facility size and pest pressure
Devices must be strategically located at entry points and vulnerable areas
Interior and exterior perimeter must have continuous device coverage
Device placement must be based on pest risk assessment
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual pest control device coverage assessment, verification against facility pest control map
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Monthly verification that all devices are present and functional, immediate placement of additional devices if gaps identified

requirements.text: Are all pest control devices identified by a number or other code (e.g. barcode)?
mandatoryStatements: All pest control devices must have unique identification numbers or barcodes
Device identification must enable traceability in monitoring records
Facility pest control map must show all device locations and identifiers
Identification must be durable and legible
requirements.verificationExpectations: Annual verification that all devices are properly identified and mapped, quarterly audit of identification legibility
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Verification of device identification during each monitoring event, immediate re-labeling if identification is missing or illegible

requirements.text: Are all pest control devices effective and bait stations secured?
mandatoryStatements: All pest control devices must be effective in capturing or monitoring target pests
Bait stations must be securely anchored or positioned
Devices must be maintained in functional condition
Ineffective devices must be replaced or repositioned
requirements.verificationExpectations: Quarterly assessment of device effectiveness based on capture data and pest control operator recommendations
requirements.monitoringExpectations: Weekly or monthly verification of device function and security during monitoring activities

mandatoryStatements: All products, ingredients, and packaging materials must be completely free of pests (insects, rodents, birds, reptiles, mammals) and any evidence of pest activity including droppings, gnaw marks, or nesting materials
An effective documented pest control program must be implemented and maintained with regular monitoring, trend analysis, and corrective action procedures
Pest control devices must be strategically located away from exposed food products, ingredients, work-in-progress, and packaging materials to prevent contamination
Poisonous bait stations must not be used inside the facility; only mechanical traps or non-toxic monitoring devices are permitted in food production and storage areas
All pest control devices must be uniquely identified with numbers or barcodes to enable traceability and monitoring verification
Pest control devices must be maintained in clean and intact condition with documented evidence of regular monitoring through physical marks or electronic scanning
Interior and exterior building perimeters must have adequate pest control device coverage based on facility size, pest pressure, and vulnerability assessment
All pest control devices must be properly secured and effective in capturing or monitoring target pests without creating contamination hazards to food products
capaInject: If pests or pest evidence are found in products, ingredients, or packaging, immediately quarantine all affected materials, conduct a comprehensive facility inspection, identify entry points and harborage areas, implement intensive pest control measures, and verify elimination before resuming production

Establish a comprehensive Integrated Pest Management (IPM) program that includes facility design evaluation, exclusion measures, sanitation protocols, monitoring procedures, treatment methods, and documentation requirements with defined responsibilities

When pest control devices are found too close to food contact areas, immediately relocate devices to safe distances (minimum 6 feet from exposed products), reassess device placement throughout the facility, and update the facility pest control map

If poisonous bait stations are discovered inside the facility, immediately remove them, replace with mechanical traps or glue boards, notify the pest control operator, and audit all pest control devices to ensure compliance

Implement a pest control device monitoring schedule with defined frequencies (typically weekly or monthly depending on pest pressure), clear documentation requirements, and accountability for completion with supervisory verification

When pest control devices are damaged, dirty, or missing monitoring marks, immediately clean or replace devices, conduct monitoring verification, investigate why maintenance was missed, and retrain responsible personnel

If pest control device coverage is inadequate, conduct a pest risk assessment to identify vulnerable areas, install additional devices at strategic locations, update the facility pest control map, and increase monitoring frequency in high-risk zones

Establish a corrective action protocol for any pest sighting that includes immediate capture/elimination, root cause investigation, environmental modification, increased monitoring, and verification of effectiveness before closing the incident
traceabilityInject: Maintain comprehensive pest control service records including date of service, pest control operator name and license number, areas inspected, findings, treatments applied, and recommendations
Document all pest sightings or evidence findings with date, location, pest type, severity, immediate actions taken, root cause analysis, and corrective measures implemented
Keep a current facility pest control map showing all device locations with unique identifiers, device types, and monitoring frequency requirements
Maintain pest monitoring logs for all devices showing inspection date, inspector name, findings (pest captures or evidence), device condition, and any corrective actions required
Retain trend analysis reports showing pest activity patterns over time, seasonal variations, effectiveness of control measures, and continuous improvement initiatives
Document pest control training records for facility personnel covering pest identification, reporting procedures, sanitation requirements, and emergency response protocols
Keep records of pest control product applications including product name, EPA registration number, application method, areas treated, concentration, quantity used, and re-entry intervals
Maintain facility maintenance records addressing pest exclusion measures such as door seal repairs, screen installations, structural gap filling, and drainage improvements
micro_inject: Rodents carry numerous foodborne pathogens including Salmonella, E. coli O157:H7, Listeria monocytogenes, and hantavirus that can be transmitted through feces, urine, saliva, and hair contaminating food products

Insects such as flies, cockroaches, and stored product beetles serve as mechanical vectors for pathogenic bacteria transferring Salmonella, Shigella, and Campylobacter from contaminated sources to food contact surfaces and products

Bird droppings contain high concentrations of Salmonella, Campylobacter, and E. coli and can contaminate food products, packaging materials, and production equipment when birds gain access to facilities

Pest-related contamination creates harborage conditions for pathogen growth by introducing organic matter, moisture, and nutrients that support multiplication of Listeria monocytogenes and other foodborne bacteria
Effective pest control programs prevent the accumulation of pest feces and debris that can harbor spore-forming bacteria including Clostridium botulinum and Bacillus cereus in facility environments
Poisonous rodenticides used inside facilities can contaminate food products with anticoagulant toxins or attract rodents near food contact areas, increasing rather than decreasing contamination risks
Pest monitoring devices located too close to food products can attract pests into production areas and create new contamination vectors rather than serving their intended protective function
Inadequate pest control device coverage allows pest populations to establish harborage areas that become reservoirs for pathogen persistence and recurring contamination events throughout the facility
